Zoology Field Course 2023-24

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:LIFE333
Delivery:Liverpool Campus · Online · First Semester
 
In Programmes:Biological Sciences BSc (Hons) 2021-22
Zoology BSc (Hons) 2021-22
Details
Module Title
Zoology Field Course
Short Title
Zoology Field Course
Module Code
LIFE333
Academic Year
2023-24
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Online
Delivery Periods
Semester 1
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Rajenda Whitlock
Other Staff
Julie Clark
Carl Larsen
John Lycett
Seth Barribeau
Zenobia Lewis
Sophie Cassidy
Rhianne Byrne
Assigned To
Life Sciences Curriculum Board
Rajenda Whitlock
Systems Molecular and Integrative Biology Admin
Quality Team
Marketing
Status
 
Approved
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
50
Pre-requisites
Advanced Experimental Design and Analysis 2020-21
Rationale
All proposed modifications have been discussed in depth with the full teaching team for the module and have also been discussed with the programme team and programme director. They are also based on External Examiner feedback.
The rationale for this proposal is to create better constructive alignment of course content, assessment and learning outcomes. The proposed changes will emphasise higher-order learning outcomes appropriate at UoL Level 3, and will also simplify and expedite the grading of course assessments.

More specifically, the current “experimental design proposal” (Ass. 4) has an inappropriately narrow focus on a specific subject, leading to assessment that insufficiently evaluates the students’ learning and critical abilities. The proposed new assessment (‘critical evaluation of conservation project’) will allow a more appropriately broad subject focus and assessment scope. It will test the students’ ability to critically evaluate and synthesise the goals, methods and achievements of several conservation projects, and draw conclusions. The increased breadth of Ass. 4, and its increased relevance in delivery of the learning outcomes has been reflected in a corresponding increase in weighting from 15% to 20% of module marks. As a result, we have decreased the weighting for the oral presentation (Ass. 2) from 15% to 10%.

Furthermore, the current assessment of ‘field work’ leads to teaching staff spending a large amount of time marking the quality of field notebooks, emphasising relatively low-level learning outcomes. This will be replaced by the new assessment ‘Approach and Contribution’ which will test the Students’ contribution to, and involvement with, seminars, site visits, group working and discussions, as well as their ability to work safely and with due ethical care in a field environment. The marking of ‘approach and contribution’ is widely and successfully used in the School, and a detailed marking rubric is provided to students beforehand. The maximum number of students on the course is 50 (but is usually in practice less than 40). Thus (i) the approach and contribution of each student can and will be assessed objectively and (ii) the staff to student ratios are such that there is ample opportunity for staff to assess this component of each student’s performance.

The new learning outcome ‘To critically evaluate different strategies for the in-situ and ex-situ conservation of animal species’ reflects the conservation aspects of the module’s content.

Module description, content and aims have been edited to reflect the revised LOs, assessments and mappings, ensuring that the nature of the course is made clear to students who wish to take it.
Blurb
Overview
This module is a field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6. It lasts for ten days and students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental design through a mixture of lectures, discussion sessions, staff-led field visits and student-executed research projects. It will be delivered partly online and partly in the field through online synchronous tutorials, and asynchronous seminars, group work, self-directed learning". It will assessed by afield report, a critical evaluation and an animated video
Educational Aims
​ To develop students’ proficiency in a range of field techniques, as well as team-working skills such as coordinating responsibility for collecting data using diverse techniques and sampling protocols ​ To develop an understanding of the types of data that can be collected, sampling protocols and how to perform appropriate statistical analyses ​To d evelop the skills necessary to synthesise information and present scientific information in the form of both an oral presentation and a written report
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6 . It lasts for ten days and students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and student-executed research projects in the field. The field course also provides in-situ and ex-situ examples of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to observe zoologists in the workplace. It is assessed by continuous assessments. All scheduled activities take place during the residential field course, but optional tutorials to help with the analysis as well as feedback tutorials are offered on campus at the beginning of term.
Outline Syllabus
T he activities in this module are mainly based on field work, carried out by groups of students. The plann ing, execution, analysis, interpretation and write-up of the field experiments are supported by a number of lectures, seminars, discussions and tutorials, addressing the following topics: - Introduction to fieldwork-relevant background information and concepts, the ecology and habitats around the field centre ​ -  Experimental and study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques - Local conservation case studies - Estimating the abundance, diversity and distribution of animal species in the field -  Fieldwork techniques and field data collection - Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies - Writing a scientific report - Developing skills for communicating information (oral presentations) In addition, students will be introduced to in-situ and ex-situ c onservation biology projects in the vicinity of the field centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled synchronous and asynchronous online lecture contents.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to synchronous online seminars on the field course
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to synchronous online tutorial group discussions on the field course
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 4 - Group-work
Description: This refers to the design of group field research projects, analysis of field data and discussion of the oral video presentation. Can be completed online for those students not making field visits.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 5 - Field Work
Description: This refers to fieldwork (executing surveys and experiments and collecting and analysing data).
Attendance Recorded (for those students taking part in fieldwork): Yes

Teaching Method 6 – Structured asynchronous learning. This refers to independent learning in which the student is provided with learning materials and then carries out a series of explicit tasks that guide learning using the provided material

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: Field Report. This is a scientific report summarising practical work undertaken in the field (alternatively based on field data collected in previous years, facilitating purely online delivery). Students carry out this assessment as individuals. The report covers the field study undertaken (or a provided field project scenario and data), including methods, background, analysis and interpretation of field data.
Assessment 2: Critical Evaluation of Conservation Projects. This is an assessment in which students critically evaluate, and compare, conservation projects, following site visits (alternatively, based on online materials describing conservation projects visited in previous years, allowing fully online delivery). This written coursework is completed individually .
Assessment 3: Animated video presentation. using Powtoon https://www.powtoon.com/ and/or Flipgrid https://info.flipgrid.com/. Students present their their field project and its results (either from their own project or from one of the provided field project scenarios) in the form of a recorded video presentation aimed at science communication to a lay audience. Instead of being structured as a formal scientific oral presentation, the students are encouraged to use alternative narrative structures that maximise the impact of the presentation for lay audiences. Assessment marks for the component assessments are aggregated to produce the final module mark. Assessment 3 (Oral Presentation), cannot be marked anonymously because the students can be identified from their presentations.
Reassessment strategy: there is a reassessment in the normal reassessment window. The reassessments will be in the same format as the original tasks and will be capped at 40%.

Instead of being structured as a formal scientific oral presentation, the students are encouraged to use alternative narrative structures that maximise the impact of the presentation for lay audiences. Assessment marks for the component assessments are aggregated to produce the final module mark. Assessment 3 (Oral Presentation), cannot be marked anonymously because the students can be identified from their presentations.
Reassessment strategy: there is a reassessment in the normal reassessment window. The reassessments will be in the same format as the original tasks and will be capped at 40%.

Zoology Field Course 2023-24

Org Unit:Life Sciences NEW
Level:Level 6
Credits:15
Module Code:LIFE333
Delivery:Liverpool Campus · Online · First Semester
 
In Programmes:Biological Sciences BSc (Hons) 2021-22
Zoology BSc (Hons) 2021-22
Details
Module Title
Zoology Field Course
Short Title
Zoology Field Course
Module Code
LIFE333
Academic Year
2023-24
Org Unit
Life Sciences NEW
Delivery Locations
Liverpool campus
Online
Delivery Periods
Semester 1
Credits
15
Level
Level 6
Module Coordinator
Rajenda Whitlock
Other Staff
Julie Clark
Carl Larsen
John Lycett
Seth Barribeau
Zenobia Lewis
Sophie Cassidy
Rhianne Byrne
Assigned To
Life Sciences Curriculum Board
Rajenda Whitlock
Systems Molecular and Integrative Biology Admin
Quality Team
Marketing
Status
 
Approved
Continuing Professional Development
No
Maximum Places
50
Pre-requisites
Advanced Experimental Design and Analysis 2020-21
Rationale
All proposed modifications have been discussed in depth with the full teaching team for the module and have also been discussed with the programme team and programme director. They are also based on External Examiner feedback.
The rationale for this proposal is to create better constructive alignment of course content, assessment and learning outcomes. The proposed changes will emphasise higher-order learning outcomes appropriate at UoL Level 3, and will also simplify and expedite the grading of course assessments.

More specifically, the current “experimental design proposal” (Ass. 4) has an inappropriately narrow focus on a specific subject, leading to assessment that insufficiently evaluates the students’ learning and critical abilities. The proposed new assessment (‘critical evaluation of conservation project’) will allow a more appropriately broad subject focus and assessment scope. It will test the students’ ability to critically evaluate and synthesise the goals, methods and achievements of several conservation projects, and draw conclusions. The increased breadth of Ass. 4, and its increased relevance in delivery of the learning outcomes has been reflected in a corresponding increase in weighting from 15% to 20% of module marks. As a result, we have decreased the weighting for the oral presentation (Ass. 2) from 15% to 10%.

Furthermore, the current assessment of ‘field work’ leads to teaching staff spending a large amount of time marking the quality of field notebooks, emphasising relatively low-level learning outcomes. This will be replaced by the new assessment ‘Approach and Contribution’ which will test the Students’ contribution to, and involvement with, seminars, site visits, group working and discussions, as well as their ability to work safely and with due ethical care in a field environment. The marking of ‘approach and contribution’ is widely and successfully used in the School, and a detailed marking rubric is provided to students beforehand. The maximum number of students on the course is 50 (but is usually in practice less than 40). Thus (i) the approach and contribution of each student can and will be assessed objectively and (ii) the staff to student ratios are such that there is ample opportunity for staff to assess this component of each student’s performance.

The new learning outcome ‘To critically evaluate different strategies for the in-situ and ex-situ conservation of animal species’ reflects the conservation aspects of the module’s content.

Module description, content and aims have been edited to reflect the revised LOs, assessments and mappings, ensuring that the nature of the course is made clear to students who wish to take it.
Blurb
Overview
This module is a field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6. It lasts for ten days and students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental design through a mixture of lectures, discussion sessions, staff-led field visits and student-executed research projects. It will be delivered partly online and partly in the field through online synchronous tutorials, and asynchronous seminars, group work, self-directed learning". It will assessed by afield report, a critical evaluation and an animated video
Educational Aims
​ To develop students’ proficiency in a range of field techniques, as well as team-working skills such as coordinating responsibility for collecting data using diverse techniques and sampling protocols ​ To develop an understanding of the types of data that can be collected, sampling protocols and how to perform appropriate statistical analyses ​To d evelop the skills necessary to synthesise information and present scientific information in the form of both an oral presentation and a written report
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is a residential field course that usually takes place in late August/early September, prior to the start of Level 6 . It lasts for ten days and students learn a variety of field skills, including observational study of animal behaviour, field ecology, and experimental design through a mixture of formal lectures, tutorial discussion groups, staff-led field visits and student-executed research projects in the field. The field course also provides in-situ and ex-situ examples of conservation projects and gives students the opportunity to observe zoologists in the workplace. It is assessed by continuous assessments. All scheduled activities take place during the residential field course, but optional tutorials to help with the analysis as well as feedback tutorials are offered on campus at the beginning of term.
Outline Syllabus
T he activities in this module are mainly based on field work, carried out by groups of students. The plann ing, execution, analysis, interpretation and write-up of the field experiments are supported by a number of lectures, seminars, discussions and tutorials, addressing the following topics: - Introduction to fieldwork-relevant background information and concepts, the ecology and habitats around the field centre ​ -  Experimental and study design in the field, including review of appropriate statistical techniques - Local conservation case studies - Estimating the abundance, diversity and distribution of animal species in the field -  Fieldwork techniques and field data collection - Analysis and interpretation of data from field studies - Writing a scientific report - Developing skills for communicating information (oral presentations) In addition, students will be introduced to in-situ and ex-situ c onservation biology projects in the vicinity of the field centre.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Teaching Method 1 - Lecture
Description: This refers to timetabled synchronous and asynchronous online lecture contents.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 2 - Seminar
Description: This refers to synchronous online seminars on the field course
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 3 - Tutorial
Description: This refers to synchronous online tutorial group discussions on the field course
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 4 - Group-work
Description: This refers to the design of group field research projects, analysis of field data and discussion of the oral video presentation. Can be completed online for those students not making field visits.
Attendance Recorded: Yes

Teaching Method 5 - Field Work
Description: This refers to fieldwork (executing surveys and experiments and collecting and analysing data).
Attendance Recorded (for those students taking part in fieldwork): Yes

Teaching Method 6 – Structured asynchronous learning. This refers to independent learning in which the student is provided with learning materials and then carries out a series of explicit tasks that guide learning using the provided material

“Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.”
Assessment Strategy
Assessment 1: Field Report. This is a scientific report summarising practical work undertaken in the field (alternatively based on field data collected in previous years, facilitating purely online delivery). Students carry out this assessment as individuals. The report covers the field study undertaken (or a provided field project scenario and data), including methods, background, analysis and interpretation of field data.
Assessment 2: Critical Evaluation of Conservation Projects. This is an assessment in which students critically evaluate, and compare, conservation projects, following site visits (alternatively, based on online materials describing conservation projects visited in previous years, allowing fully online delivery). This written coursework is completed individually .
Assessment 3: Animated video presentation. using Powtoon https://www.powtoon.com/ and/or Flipgrid https://info.flipgrid.com/. Students present their their field project and its results (either from their own project or from one of the provided field project scenarios) in the form of a recorded video presentation aimed at science communication to a lay audience. Instead of being structured as a formal scientific oral presentation, the students are encouraged to use alternative narrative structures that maximise the impact of the presentation for lay audiences. Assessment marks for the component assessments are aggregated to produce the final module mark. Assessment 3 (Oral Presentation), cannot be marked anonymously because the students can be identified from their presentations.
Reassessment strategy: there is a reassessment in the normal reassessment window. The reassessments will be in the same format as the original tasks and will be capped at 40%.
